text: Hey everyone, I'm an Astronautical Engineer and a big fan of Julia and was hoping to apply with some JuliaAstrodynamics ideas, but the project looks dead. Does anyone know if the project is abandoned? If so, is it worth submitting ideas for?

elements.text: Hey everyone, I'm an Astronautical Engineer and a big fan of Julia and was hoping to apply with some JuliaAstrodynamics ideas, but the project looks dead. Does anyone know if the project is abandoned? If so, is it worth submitting ideas for?

text: pinging <@U8442MDS6>, who's the maintainer of the project :slightly_smiling_face:  I'm sure he'd love to hear your ideas!

elements.text: , who's the maintainer of the project
I'm sure he'd love to hear your ideas!

text: I _think_ some of the astrodynamics stuff Helge worked on now lives in <https://github.com/JuliaSpace/>  related, have you seen <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/julia-and-the-satellite-amazonia-1/57541>? :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.title: Julia and the satellite Amazonia-1
attachments.text: Hi guys! Long time, no see! As some of you may know, I am the mission architect and the technical responsible for the attitude and orbit control subsystem (AOCS) of the Brazilian satellite Amazonia-1, launched on Feb 28. This is an image obtained by the first recording procedure: Here you can see the big city of São Paulo (on the left), São José dos Campos where INPE is located (“small” city on the top right), and the beautiful Brazilian shore, showing Santos, Guarujá, Bertioga, São Sebast...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Julia and the satellite Amazonia-1

elements.text: some of the astrodynamics stuff Helge worked on now lives in

text: Actually read about SatelliteToolbox.jl the other day when it was on HackerNews but I had no idea about Julia Space. Definitely going to look into JuliaSpace more thanks!

elements.text: Actually read about SatelliteToolbox.jl the other day when it was on HackerNews but I had no idea about Julia Space. Definitely going to look into JuliaSpace more thanks!

text: JuliaSpace is the successor of JuliaAstrodynamics :+1:

elements.text: JuliaSpace is the successor of JuliaAstrodynamics

text: It looks like a really cool project. I was playing with it last night. Looking at the Github, activity on the project has been a little sporadic, but there are definitely some open issues I think I could tackle, and I'm sure I could come up with some original ideas as well. Would you be interested in working with Google Summer of Code if I put in a proposal for something JuliaSpace related?

elements.text: It looks like a really cool project. I was playing with it last night.
